frontmatter.title: Amphibious Buildings
frontmatter.excerpt: Amphibious architecture is an adaptation strategy where structures are designed to adapt to flooding.

frontmatter.title: Barrier Islands
frontmatter.excerpt: Located offshore, barrier islands are dynamic landforms that are formed from offshore bars and, spits.

frontmatter.title: Beach Nourishment
frontmatter.excerpt: Beach nourishment (beach renourishment, beach replenishment, or sand replenishment) involves a process of replacing material (usually sand) to a beach that might have been lost by longshore drift or erosion.

frontmatter.title: Breakwaters
frontmatter.excerpt: Breakwaters are linear, offshore, or onshore structures built to protect the coast from the effects of both storm surges and longshore drift.

frontmatter.title: Coastal Wetlands
frontmatter.excerpt: Coastal wetlands represent ecosystems that are permanently or seasonally inundated with either fresh, brackish, or saline water that is usually less than 6 feet in depth at low tide.

frontmatter.title: Development Permits
frontmatter.excerpt: Development permits regulate land use to ensure that areas are developed in a manner that aligns with environmental protection and the protection of ecosystems, biodiversity.

frontmatter.title: Development Transfers
frontmatter.excerpt: Transfer of Development Rights (TDR), also commonly referred to as Transfer of Development Credits (TDC), is a mechanism that is used to encourage high-density development on lands that are less susceptible to the impacts of built infrastructure within a defined region, while limiting development on ecologically sensitive lands.

frontmatter.title: Dikes
frontmatter.excerpt: Dikes are linear compacted earth structures implemented to protect coastal areas from flooding.

frontmatter.title: Dry Floodproofing
frontmatter.excerpt: Dry floodproofing is a practice of utilizing waterproof membranes and other types of sealants to prevent floodwater from entering a building.

frontmatter.title: Dune Building / Restoration
frontmatter.excerpt: Dunes develop from sand deposits that represent a store of sediment in the zone just landward of normal high tides.

frontmatter.title: Easement and Covenants
frontmatter.excerpt: An easement or covenant is a legal agreement that allows the owner of a parcel of land to grant rights to others for a designated use.

frontmatter.title: Emergency Planning Preparedness
frontmatter.excerpt: Emergency planning and preparedness is a coordinated process that involves assessing the likely impacts of a disaster event and coordinating a set of responses to reduce or prevent property damage.

frontmatter.title: Evacuation Routes
frontmatter.excerpt: Evacuation routes are accessways that are constructed above flood levels and that connect flood risk areas to mainland areas that are safely above flood plains.

frontmatter.title: Floodwalls
frontmatter.excerpt: Floodwalls are typically vertical structural barriers that are used in locations where space is limited due to buildings or other land uses.

frontmatter.title: Foreshore Tenure
frontmatter.excerpt: In British Columbia, the foreshore is defined as the land that exists between the low and high watermarks of a stream, river, lake, or ocean.

frontmatter.title: Groynes
frontmatter.excerpt: Groynes are rigid structures, typically constructed using heavy materials extending from the upper shore to the water.

frontmatter.title: Land Acquisition
frontmatter.excerpt: Land acquisition is the process of purchasing or expropriating land with the primary purpose of protecting the public interest.

frontmatter.title: Land Trust
frontmatter.excerpt: A land trust is a non-profit private organization created for the purpose of environmental conservation.

frontmatter.title: Protected Area Zoning
frontmatter.excerpt: Zoning is a process that gives local and national agencies the autonomy to regulate land use.

frontmatter.title: Reef Systems
frontmatter.excerpt: Reefs are under and near water ecosystems that provide protection against flooding and erosion.

frontmatter.title: Scour Protection
frontmatter.excerpt: Scours are property-specific structural tools that are used to protect shoreline structures or building foundations from exposure to the corrosive effects of moving water.

frontmatter.title: Seawall
frontmatter.excerpt: Seawalls are hard engineered structures built parallel to the shoreline.

frontmatter.title: Secondary Dikes
frontmatter.excerpt: Secondary dikes work in conjunction with primary dikes to reduce the impact of a flood if the primary dike is breached.

frontmatter.title: Storm Surge Barriers
frontmatter.excerpt: Storm surge barriers are heavily engineered movable or fixed barriers/gates that are closed to prevent flooding during bad weather forecasts.

frontmatter.title: Subdivision Regulation and Development Control
frontmatter.excerpt: A subdivision regulation is a planning tool that can be used to establish conditions for the protection against environmental hazards, e.g., coastal hazards related to sea-level rise.

frontmatter.title: Warning System
frontmatter.excerpt: Early warning systems form an important element of disaster risk management.

frontmatter.title: Wet Floodproofing
frontmatter.excerpt: Wet floodproofing is the measure of allowing water to enter and exit a structure with minimal or no damage.
